pros: Helping the students at St. Ambrose is rewarding. Most individual faculty and staff members are very kind and caring people. Most supervisors and positions have good flexibility on hours.
cons:
Heavy work loads, and low pay. 
The administration does not respond constructively to feedback from faculty and staff. 
The observation that the administration plans budgets poorly and creates constant yearly budget crises is spot-on. 
The administration also keeps several key parts of the budget secret, especially athletics (which, unlike NCAA institutions, St. Ambrose as a NAIA program is not required to keep separate from the overall university budget).

pros:
- Student worker hours are flexible around class scheduling.
- Supervisors understand the school comes first.
- Great opportunity for professional networking.
- Some positions offer major-focused skill development.
cons:
- Minimum wage for student workers.
- Most student worker positions are busy-work.
- Few student worker positions offer things that make a real impact on a resume.

pros:
Small campus and everyone knows each other. 
The relationships between students and professors are very close. The benefits are acceptable.
 The health insurance was okay but it will be very hard to change after you make the choice.
Free parking on campus for employees.
cons:
No summer teaching opportunities. 
No relocation fee and starting fee. 
The teaching load is very high and compensation is not matched with the time spent on teaching, research and service.

pros: The greatest benefit is free housing for the students. The culture is fantastic as well. Has a tremendous family vibe.
cons: Inconsistent policy enforcement which drives student dissent and lack of trust to administration.

pros: Free parking for staff and faculty, on-site meals, great co-workers, good work-life balance
cons: Very low paying salary and new employees do not get vacation time for 1-2 years after start date (depending on date date) as vacation time is given in September for employees after the first year of employment

review_title: Graduate Assistance in International Admission office
pros: People here are nice. I have a very good time working here. Time are flexible and I learned a lot here.
cons: I expect pay to be higher.
Poor, old-school, top-down management style with an Old Boys Club feel.

pros: Not much. Benefits are below average, not even relocation compensation.
cons: Not for career development. If you wanna a teaching job and spend the rest of your life for teaching only, you may consider it. Faculties I've worked with have neither motivation for research nor passion for advancing teaching methods.

job_title: Campus Security Officer in Davenport, IA
pros:
Great lead shift officers
Lots of time to do homework on the job
cons:
Minimum pay
Late at night
Paid once a month

pros: Great Hours, fringe benefits, people to work with!
cons: Must have a PhD to get tenure track

pros: Great colleagues and fun collaborations across disciplines!
cons: Salaries are somewhat below national averages.
